step1.para: Use floor stands to support vehicle.

warning.para: A jack must never be used alone to support a vehicle while under-chassis service is being performed. The jack may lower and serious personal injury could result. Always support vehicle with floor stands.

step1.para: As brake pad lining wears, the piston travel increases and the brake fluid level in the reservoir lowers. Before servicing the caliper assemblies, inspect the fluid level. If the fluid level is full or near full, remove some fluid from the reservoir. When the piston is pushed back into the caliper cylinder bores, the fluid will be forced back to the reservoir and may overflow if not removed. Discard the used brake fluid.
The caliper assembly must be removed from the rotor before the hub and rotor can be removed.

During service procedures, avoid getting grease, oil and foreign materials on the caliper assembly. Handle parts carefully to avoid damage, especially to the brake hoses and lines. Do not let the caliper hang freely; support the caliper. If caliper is not supported and left to hang freely, possible damage to the caliper brake flex hose could occur.

If inspection reveals that caliper piston seals or dust boots are leaking or damaged, replace them
( Figure 8and Figure 9).

step1.para: Inspect wheel bearing assemblies for wear or damage when servicing brakes, adjust wheel bearings after brake service is completed and before wheels are installed. Refer to GROUP 17 - WHEELS, RIMS AND TIRES in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

When installing the tire and rim assembly on disc braked axles, make sure the tire valve stem clears the brake caliper. The use of a valve stem retainer or a tire manufacturer's stem forming tool are recommended to obtain clearance if necessary.
In the event the original brake pads are to be used again, mark pads so that they are reinstalled in the same location.
After any brake service, test brakes for proper operation before putting vehicle back in service.
